questions.text:
Which of the following agents is most likely causing the condition in a 60-year-old woman, who had a kidney transplant 2 months ago, and is now experiencing a high fever, severe difficulty in breathing, and a dry cough with a hacking sound?

A chest x-ray shows widespread interstitial infiltrates in both lungs, and urine examination reveals the presence of cells with an 'owl-eye' appearance.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cytomegalovirus

Explanation:

  • Cytomegalovirus infection is the most common opportunistic infection post renal transplantation, and it usually occurs within 1- 6 months of transplantation.

Complications following Renal transplant

Graft rejection

Hyperacute, acute and chronic

Opportunistic infections

 
  • < 1 Month: Wound infection, HSV, UTI, Oral candidiasis
  • 1-6 Months: CMV (most common), HBV, HCV, Pneumocystis carinii, Listeria
  • >6 Months: BK Virus, Aspergillus, Nocardia, HBV, HCV, HZV

Hypercalcemia

This may indicate failure of parathyroid gland regression post-transplant.

Anemia

Common post-transplant, often due to immunosuppressive medications. Gastrointestinal bleeding can occur from steroid use.

Chronic hepatitis

Particularly from hepatitis B virus, which can progress over time.

Skin and lip cancers

Most common malignancy

The leading causes of death among kidney transplant recipients include:

  • Cardiovascular events (29%)
  • Infections (18%)
  • Malignancies (17%)

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of episodes of palpitations, headache, and profuse sweating for the past few days. MIBG scan shows a deep-seated tumour in the adrenal medulla. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition described?

choices.text: Surgical excision is the definitive treatment
Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension

Explanation:

The above condition is characteristic of pheochromocytoma.

  • Episodes of palpitations, profuse sweating, and headache constitute a classic triad of pheochromocytoma.
  • The diagnosis is typically confirmed by measuring urine vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and catecholamine levels, and the definitive treatment is surgical excision.
  • However, the initial management of hypertension in pheochromocytoma involves starting with an alpha-blocker to prevent a hypertensive crisis. Beta-blockers like propranolol are only added after adequate alpha blockade is established to avoid unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, which could worsen the hypertension.

Pheochromocytoma

Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumours arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • The dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Vomiting (Option D)
  • Pain abdomen
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines (Option A)
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines
  • Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) (a metabolite of adrenaline and noradrenaline) (Option A)

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumour.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection. (Option B)
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers (phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight) (vs Option C)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/kg, and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hyponatremia

Explanation:

  • The serum osmolality is low (270 mOsm/kg, below the normal 285–295 mOsm/kg), indicating a diluted serum, while the high urine osmolality (1000 mOsm/kg) shows that the kidneys are still concentrating urine. This pattern is characteristic of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia, most commonly seen in SIADH, where inappropriate ADH secretion leads to water retention and dilution of serum sodium. This severe dilutional hyponatremia can lower sodium levels enough to trigger seizures.

Causes of euvolemic (dilutional) hyponatremia include:

  • Drugs (desmopressin, oxytocin, antidepressants, opioids, thiazide diuretics, carbamazepine or its analogues, vincristine, nicotine, antipsychotics, chlorpropamide, cyclophosphamide, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, MDMA)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH)
    • Increased ADH leads to water retention with near-normal sodium levels.
    • Water overload leads to the release of ANP ( Atrial natriuretic peptide) from atria.
    • ANP causes natriuresis which leads to euvolemic hyponatremia.
    • No edema occurs.
    • Causes of SIADH:
      • Tumours
      • Central nervous system disorders: stroke, trauma, infection, psychosis, porphyria
      • Pulmonary disorders: pneumonia, tuberculosis, obstructive lung disease
      • Drugs: anticonvulsants, psychotropics, antidepressants, cytotoxics, oral hypoglycaemic agents, opiates
      • Idiopathic
  • Addison's disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • High fluid intake in conditions like primary polydipsia or potomania, caused by a low intake of solutes with relatively high fluid intake
  • Medical testing related to excessive fluids, such as a colonoscopy or cardiac catheterisation
  • Iatrogenic

Incorrect Options:

Plasma osmolality in hypernatremia (Option A) would typically be associated with increased serum osmolality (>295 mOsm/kg) due to a deficit of water in relation to sodium.

Hyperkalemia (Option C) refers to an elevated level of potassium in the blood. It is not related to the given scenario as it occurs in conditions of metabolic acidosis, particularly in kidney disease, where potassium excretion is impaired.

Hypokalemia (Option D) is a condition characterized by a low level of potassium in the blood. It is caused by diuretics, GI losses, and hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: Hemodialysis is an indication for all the below conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peripheral Neuropathy

Explanation:

  • Peripheral neuropathy in CKD patients develops gradually and is less likely to improve rapidly with hemodialysis. It often requires long-term management of underlying renal disease and symptomatic treatment rather than acute dialysis.

Indications of Hemodialysis:

Indication

Acute (AKI)

Chronic(CKD)

Fluid Overload
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pulmonary Edema
  • Severe Hypertension
  • Edema resistant to diuretics

Hyperkalemia
  • >6.5 mmol/L with ECG changes (Broad QRS)
  • Potassium resistant to treatment

Uraemia
  • Pericarditis (Option D)
  • Encephalopathy (Option A)
  • Uremic syndrome (anorexia, nausea, lethargy, etc.), typically when eGFR < 10 mL/min/1.73 m²

Metabolic Acidosis

(Option C)
  • Severe acidosis(H+ > 79 nmol/L; pH < 7.1)
  • Chronic acidosis resistant to bicarbonate therapy

Relative indications
  • Bleeding diathesis due to uremia-induced platelet dysfunction
  • Intractable anemia despite erythropoietin and iron supplementation
  • Hyperphosphatemia despite phosphate binders

questions.text: A patient has undergone an acute renal allograft transplantation. What would indicate its rejection?

choices.text: Rise of creatinine by more than 10% is suggestive of acute rejection.
Rise of creatinine by more than 5% is suggestive of acute rejection.
Serum creatinine does not rise in acute renal allograft rejection.
Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Any rise in serum creatinine will be suggestive of acute renal allograft rejection.

 

Explanation:

  • After renal allograft transplantation, serum creatinine is one of the earliest and most sensitive indicators of graft dysfunction.
  • A rise in serum creatinine, even if small or unexplained, necessitates further investigation to rule out acute rejection.

 

Acute Renal Allograft Rejection

  • Acute renal allograft rejection occurs when the recipient's immune system identifies the transplanted kidney as foreign, leading to cellular or antibody-mediated immune responses that cause kidney inflammation and damage.

 

Clinical Presentation:

  • Typically occurs weeks to months post-transplant, but can occur later if immunosuppression is reduced.
  • Symptoms may include reduced urine output, graft tenderness, fever, and malaise, though not always present.
  • Any unexplained increase in creatinine should raise suspicion for acute rejection.

 

Types of Acute Rejection:

  • Cellular Rejection (T-cell Mediated): T-cells attack the graft, causing inflammation and tissue damage.
  • Antibody-Mediated Rejection (AMR): Antibodies attack the donor endothelial cells, leading to endothelial injury and microvascular thrombosis.

Confirmatory Investigation:

  • Renal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing acute rejection and determining the type of rejection.
  • Biopsy findings:
    • Cellular rejection: T-cell infiltration and inflammation.
    • AMR: Endothelial damage and microvascular inflammation.

Treatment:

  • Cellular rejection: Treated with increased immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., steroids, ATG).
  • AMR: Requires treatments like plasmapheresis, IVIG, or rituximab.

 

Type of Rejection

Hyperacute Rejection

Acute Rejection

Chronic Rejection

Acute Cellular Rejection

Acute Antibody-Mediated Rejection

Description
  • Occurs immediately after transplant.
  • Mediated by preformed antibodies against graft endothelial cells.
  • Occurs within days to weeks after transplant.
  • Mediated by CD8+ T cells and CD4+ T cells.

Antibodies bind to graft endothelial cells, leading to complement activation and inflammation.
  • Develops over months to years.
  • Mediated by T cells.

Timing

Minutes to hours after transplant.

Days to weeks after transplant.

Days to months after transplant.

Months to years after transplant.

Type of Hypersensitivity Reaction

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Type 2 (Cytotoxic Hypersensitivity)

Type 4 (Cell-mediated Hypersensitivity)

Immunologic Mechanism
  • Pre-existing antibodies activate complement.
  • Causes endothelial injury and thrombosis.
  • CD8+ T cells destroy graft cells.
  • CD4+ T cells induce inflammation.
  • Antibodies against graft antigens activate complement.
  • Leads to graft inflammation.

T cell-mediated response causes graft fibrosis and dysfunction.

Treatment
  • No treatment.
  • Requires graft removal.

Immunosuppressive therapy (steroids, antithymocyte globulin).

Plasmapheresis, IVIG, rituximab, steroids.
  • No definitive treatment.
  • Supportive care and immunosuppression.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the casualty with severe shortness of breath and fatigue for the past 3 hours. He reports a history of vomiting and epigastric pain 2 days back, for which he took an anti-emetic. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 1. As the CBG valve of this patient showed 356mg/dL, the physician advises immediate ABG analysis, which reveals a pH=7.32, pCO2=38mEq/L, and HCO3-=15mEq/L. This report showed a type of acidosis with an increased anion gap. Which of the following conditions does not belong to the same classification of metabolic acidosis as in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Renal aciduria

  • Renal aciduria refers to a condition characterized by the inability of the kidneys to effectively reabsorb bicarbonate or excrete hydrogen ions, leading to a decreased bicarbonate and metabolic acidosis. However, renal aciduria presents with normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA). It is a form of renal tubular acidosis (RTA).

Metabolic acidosis

High anion gap (MUDPILES)

(HAGMA)

Non-anion gap (USED PART)

(NAGMA)
  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia: AKI, CKD (Option A)
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Paracetamol poisoning
  • Iron and isoniazid
  • Lactic acidosis (Option B)
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning (Option D)
  • U: Urinary diversion / Ureterenterostomy
  • S: Small Bowel Fistula, Spironolactone and K-sparing diuretics, Saline infusion (rapid infusion)
  • E: Extra Chloride
  • D: Diarrhea
  • P: Pancreatic fistula
  • A: Addison, Acetazolamide
  • R: RTA (Renal tubular acidosis )
  • T: Tenofovir, Topiramate

Reduced anion gap: Multiple myeloma and nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents with multiple oral and genital ulcers. The patient claims these ulcers resolve spontaneously and that she experiences such episodes at least four times a year. Ocular examination reveals features of anterior uveitis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Behcet’s disease

Explanation:
This patient presents with classic features of Behcet's Disease:

  • Young adult male
  • Mucocutaneous manifestations (oral/genital ulcers)
  • Ocular involvement (uveitis)

Behcet's disease is a chronic autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers. It is a multi-systemic vasculitis that can affect blood vessels of all sizes. One of the common manifestations of Behcet's disease is uveitis

Behcet’s Disease- Pathogenesis and Clinical Features

Category

Features

Clinical Significance

Pathogenesis
  • T-cell mediated immunity
  • Th1 cell activation
  • Elevated cytokines (IL-1, TNF-α)
  • Neutrophilic vasculitis
  • No specific autoantibodies
  • Auto-inflammatory rather than autoimmune
  • Affects vessels of all sizes
  • Treatment targets inflammation

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral ulcers (97-99%)
  • Genital ulcers (>80%)
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Pathergy reaction
  • Often initial presentation
  • Oral ulcers heal without scarring
  • Genital ulcers leave scars

Major Organ Involvement
  • Uveitis (>50%)
  • Vascular (25%)
  • Neurologic (5-10%)
  • Arthritis (non-erosive)
  • More severe in males
  • Ocular disease can cause blindness
  • Vascular involvement can be fatal

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes an ideal candidate for a renal graft transplant in a patient with diabetic nephropathy?

choices.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year
The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant
The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

Explanation:

  • Renal transplantation is considered the treatment of choice for end-stage renal disease (ESRD) in patients with diabetic nephropathy with eGFR <20 ml/min.

Renal transplant procedure:

  • Preparation of the donor kidney: inspected and examined. The left kidney is preferred as it has a longer left renal vein.

Operative technique:

  • The donor kidney is transplanted into one of the iliac fossae (retroperitoneal location) leaving the native kidney in situ. Hence, a total of 3 kidneys in the recipient.
  • The donor renal vein is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac vein.
  • In a cadaveric donor, the renal artery is anastomosed end to side to the external or common iliac artery.
  • In live donors, end-to-end anastomosis to the divided internal iliac artery is used more commonly due to the lack of an aortic patch (Carrel’s patch).

Indications for renal transplantation:

  • End-stage renal disease caused by:
    • Glomerulonephritis
    • Diabetic nephropathy
    • Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
    • Renal vascular disease
    • Polycystic Kidney disease/Chronic Pyelonephritis
    • Obstructive uropathy
    • SLE
    • Analgesic nephropathy
    • Metabolic disease (oxalosis, amyloid)
  • Mnemonic: GD for HR POSt at 4 AM

 

"The survival rate of the graft is 95% in the first year," (Option A) is an overgeneralization. While the survival rate of renal grafts in the first year can be relatively high, it is not consistently 95% for all patients.

"The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant," (Option C) is not entirely accurate. While renal transplantation can improve the quality of life and increase life expectancy in patients with ESRD, it does not necessarily double the life expectancy.

"The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years," (Option D) is not directly addressed in the given statement. Chronic rejection remains a challenge in renal transplantation.

questions.text: Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient, who weighs 60 kg, using the provided serum electrolyte values: pH of 7.42, sodium (Na+) level of 120 mEq/L, and serum chloride (CI-) level of 90 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)720 mEq

Explanation:

  • Sodium Deficit Formula:
    • Sodium deficit = (Desired Na⁺ - Actual Na⁺) × Total Body Water (TBW)

Total Body Water (TBW):

  • TBW = 0.6 × Body Weight(for males)
  • = 0.5 x Body Weight(for females)

TBW for this patient: 0.6 × 60 kg = 36 litres

Desired Sodium Increase:

  • The target increase in serum sodium = 140 mEq/L - 120 mEq/L = 20 mEq/L

Sodium Deficit Calculation:

  • Sodium deficit = 20 mEq/L × 36 L = 720mEq

 

Safe Increase in Sodium:

  • In acute symptomatic hyponatremia with seizures, an initial rapid correction of 4-6 mEq/L in the first few hours is recommended to stabilize neurological symptoms.
  • The total correction should not exceed 8-12 mEq/L in the first 24 hours to avoid complications such as osmotic demyelination syndrome.

questions.text: In the given acid-base nomogram diagram, areas marked A and D indicated which of the following conditions?

choices.text: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
Acute metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis

Explanation:

A - Acute respiratory acidosis occurs when there is an increase in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) in the blood due to inadequate ventilation. This can be caused by conditions such as pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or airway obstruction.

D - Acute respiratory alkalosis occurs when there is a decrease in PaCO2 in the blood due to excessive ventilation. It can be caused by hyperventilation due to anxiety, fever, or high altitude.

 

Acid-base disorders

Simple acid-base disorders and their compensatory mechanisms:

  • Primary respiratory disturbances (changes in PaCO₂) lead to metabolic compensation (changes in [HCO₃⁻]).
  • Primary metabolic disturbances (changes in [HCO₃⁻]) lead to respiratory compensation (changes in PaCO₂).
  • Compensation moves pH toward normal, but typically does not fully correct it, except for chronic respiratory alkalosis, which may restore normal pH.
  • Metabolic acidosis (e.g., from ketoacidosis or lactic acidosis) lowers [HCO₃⁻] and extracellular pH, triggers ventilation (lowers PaCO₂) to compensate.
  • Winter’s equation predicts expected PaCO₂ in metabolic acidosis:
  • PaCO₂= (1.5×[HCO3−]) + 8 ± 2
    • Example: If [HCO₃⁻] = 12 mmol/L, expected PaCO₂ ≈ 26 mmHg ± 2
    • If PaCO₂ is <24 mmHg or >28 mmHg, a mixed disorder (e.g., metabolic acidosis + respiratory alkalosis/acidosis) is likely to be present.
    • Compensation direction:
    • Metabolic disorders: PaCO₂ moves in same direction as [HCO₃⁻].
    • Respiratory disorders: [HCO₃⁻] moves in same direction as PaCO₂.

Mixed acid-base disorders and the use of an acid-base nomogram:

  • Opposing Changes Indicate a Mixed Disorder:
    • If PaCO₂ and [HCO₃⁻] move in opposite directions (one increases while the other decreases), a mixed acid-base disorder is present.
    • Example: PaCO₂ increases (respiratory acidosis) while [HCO₃⁻] decreases (metabolic acidosis) → Mixed acidosis.
  • Acid-Base Nomogram:
    • An acid-base nomogram is a graphical tool used to analyze and interpret acid-base disturbances in the body. It helps in determining the primary acid-base disorder and assessing compensatory responses.
    • The nomogram typically consists of a graph with axes representing the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2 ) and the bicarbonate (HCO3-) concentration.
    • The diagonal lines on the graph represent different levels of blood pH.
    • The shaded areas represent the 95% confidence limits for compensation in simple disorders.
    • Values within the shaded area do not rule out a mixed disorder, since overlapping conditions might mimic a different disorder.

  • Equations vs Nomogram:
     
    • The nomogram is useful but not a substitute for calculations.
    • Equations like Winter’s equation provide a more precise assessment of compensation.

Disorder

Prediction of Compensation

Range of Values (pH, HCO₃⁻, PaCO₂)

Metabolic Acidosis

PaCO₂ = (1.5 × HCO₃⁻) + 8 ± 2 /

PaCO₂ ↓ 1.25 mmHg per mmol/L ↓ in HCO₃⁻ /

PaCO₂ = HCO₃⁻ + 15

Low, Low, Low

Metabolic Alkalosis

PaCO₂ ↑ 0.75 mmHg per mmol/L ↑ in HCO₃⁻

PaCO₂ ↑ 6 mmHg per 10 mmol/L ↑ in HCO₃⁻

PaCO₂ = HCO₃⁻ + 15

High, High, High

Respiratory Alkalosis

Acute: HCO₃⁻ ↓ 0.2 mmol/L per mmHg ↓ in PaCO₂ Chronic: HCO₃⁻ ↓ 0.4 mmol/L per mmHg ↓ in PaCO₂

High, Low, Low

Respiratory Acidosis

Acute: HCO₃⁻ ↑ 0.1 mmol/L per mmHg ↑ in PaCO₂

Chronic: HCO₃⁻ ↑ 0.4 mmol/L per mmHg ↑ in PaCO₂

Low, High, High

questions.text: A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Nephrogenic DI
 

  • A mutation in the gene for the aquaporin channel leads to Nephrogenic DI.

Diabetes Insipidus (DI):

  • It is a disorder characterized by excessive hypotonic urinary output (>50 mL/kg body weight per 24 hours) and polydipsia (>3 litres/day).
  • It results from an inability to concentrate urine adequately due to a deficiency or insensitivity to antidiuretic hormone (ADH).
  • Types of Diabetes Insipidus:

 

Feature

Central DI

Nephrogenic DI

Primary Polydipsia

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake, suppressing AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection has no effect on severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

Posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioral therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

Liddle’s syndrome (Option A) is caused by an inherited gain-of-function mutation in genes regulating the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) in the collecting duct.

Cystic fibrosis (Option C) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, which encodes a chloride channel in the luminal plasma membranes of epithelial cells.

Bartter syndrome (Option D) results from loss-of-function mutations in transporters and ion channels in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, most frequently affecting the Na-K-2Cl transporter.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with palpitation and weight loss. On examination of her legs the following lesion was found which on applying pressure, the indentation does not persist on release. ECG shows sinus rhythm. What is the probable cause of the oedema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myxedema

Explanation:

  • The patient has palpitations and weight loss, suggestive of hypermetabolic or hyperthyroid state.

  • The leg lesion described is a form of edema where indenting the swollen area does not leave a persistent indentation on release—this is non-pitting edema.

  • ECG shows sinus rhythm (normal heart rhythm), so no arrhythmia implying heart failure currently.

  • Myxedema causes non-pitting edema due to mucopolysaccharide (glycosaminoglycan) deposition in the skin and tissues, commonly seen in severe hypothyroidism. The edema does not pit on pressure.

Nephrotic syndrome (Option B): Causes pitting edema due to low albumin and fluid retention.

Chronic lymphangitis (Option C): Usually causes non-pitting edema along with skin changes but is an inflammatory condition often with signs of infection.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option D): Usually causes pitting edema due to heart failure and fluid overload.

questions.text: A hepatitis B-positive person came to your OPD on routine urine massive proteinuria (> 3.5 g/day). Further renal biopsy was performed as below. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Membranous glomerulonephritis

Explanation:

Investigations of Membranous Nephropathy/ glomerulonephritis:

  • Kidney function tests reveal increased creatinine
  • Urine Protein: >2gm protein/gram of urinary creatinine
  • Renal biopsy:
    • Light Microscopy: Reveals uniform basement membrane thickening along peripheral capillary loops.
  • Immunofluorescence: Diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3
  • Electron Microscopy: Dense subepithelial deposits
    • Spike & dome appearance (arrows & asterisk)
  • Autoantibody Testing:
    • Autoantibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) are present in 70% of cases.
    • Thrombospondin type-1 domain containing 7A (THSD7A) (3-10%)
    • Secondary MGN often lacks these autoantibodies.

Management of Membranous Nephropathy:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Manage oedema (Thiazide diuretics), dyslipidemia, and hypertension (ACE inhibitors/ARBs)
  • Immunosuppressive Therapy: For primary MGN with persistent proteinuria (>3g/24 h)
    • Corticosteroids
    • Cyclophosphamide
    • Chlorambucil
    • Mycophenolate mofetil
    • Cyclosporine
    • Rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody)
  • Prophylactic Anticoagulation may be recommended for patients with hypoalbuminemia due to the risk of thrombotic complications.

Complications:

  • Increased risk of Renal vein thrombosis.
  • Others: Deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to hypercoagulability associated with nephrotic syndrome.

Prognosis:

  • One-third of patients progress to more severe disease.
  • One-third experience spontaneous remission.
  • One-third maintain stable disease.
  • Factors associated with a poorer prognosis include male gender, older age, hypertension, and persistent nephrotic-range proteinuria.

Incorrect Options:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Option A) is characterized by scarring and sclerosis of certain glomeruli in a focal and segmental pattern.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) (Option C) is characterized by both thickening and proliferation of the glomerular basement membrane.

Minimal change disease (Option D) is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children but is less common in adults.

questions.text: Which of the following options represents the most severe manifestation of Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hyperkalaemia

Explanation:

Hyperkalaemia (greater than 5.0 mEq/L) is considered as one of the most severe manifestations of chronic kidney disease (CKD) (normal range: 3.5-5.0 mEq/L). As kidney function declines, the ability of the kidneys to excrete potassium decreases, leading to its accumulation. Symptoms may include muscle weakness, fatigue, palpitations, and, in severe cases, cardiac arrest.

 

Chronic Kidney Disease

Leading causes

  • Diabetic nephropathy (Most common)
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Hypertension
  • Ischemic heart disease (Cardiorenal syndrome)
  • Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
  • Tubulointerstitial kidney disease

Manifestations
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea
  • Electrolyte Imbalances
  • Hiccups (urea irritates gastric mucosa)
  • Pedal oedema
  • Muscle cramping and twitching
  • Pruritus and skin pigmentation
  • Uremic fetor
  • Restless leg syndrome
  • Uremic pericarditis
  • Hypertension

 

Fluid and serum electrolytes in CKD

Electrolyte Imbalances

Management

Hypervolemic hyponatremia:

  • High circulating aldosterone levels.
  • Increase in water > sodium retention.
  • Water restriction

Hyperkalemia
  • Patiromer
  • Calcium resonium
  • Sodium polystyrene
  • Calcium gluconate or calcium chloride (for cardiac protection).
  • Insulin and glucose (to shift potassium back into cells)

Hypokalemia (rare): Usually due to overuse of diuretics
  • Increase dietary intake and reduce the dose of diuretics

Hyperphosphatemia

  • Sevelamer
  • Calcium acetate or carbonate

Hypocalcemia
  • Paricalcitol

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Decreased glomerular filtration rate (Option A) (GFR) is a hallmark of CKD and represents impaired kidney function. While decreased GFR is a key diagnostic criterion for CKD, it alone does not indicate the severity of the disease. The progression of CKD and its complications, such as hyperkalemia, are influenced by factors beyond the GFR.

Increased creatinine (Option B) levels are indicative of reduced kidney function in CKD, they do not directly reflect the severity of the disease. Creatinine levels can also vary depending on various factors, including muscle mass, age, and hydration status.

Proteinuria (Option D), the presence of excess protein in the urine, is a common finding in CKD. While it is an important marker of kidney damage and can be associated with disease progression, it is not considered the most severe manifestation of CKD.

questions.text: A patient exhibits symptoms of increased urination, nighttime urination, and involuntary urination, along with a recorded 24-hour urine volume of 7 litres. He has a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L. The ADH assay shows a recorded value of 0.8 pg/ml, and an MRI of the brain reveals the absence of a bright spot on T1-weighted imaging. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pituitary DI

Explanation:

  • The above case is most suggestive of pituitary diabetes insipidus. The absence of a pituitary bright spot is suggestive of central DI.

Feature

Central DI

(Option C)

Nephrogenic DI

(Option A)

Primary Polydipsia

(Option B)

Gestational DI

Definition

Deficiency of AVP (Arginine vasopressin) secretion from the pituitary gland.

Kidneys are unable to respond to AVP, even if levels are normal.

Excessive water intake suppresses AVP secretion.

Increased activity of placental enzyme degrading AVP during pregnancy.

Causes

Acquired: Head trauma, tumours, granulomas, infections, inflammation, toxins, vascular events, hypoxia.

 

Acquired: Drugs (lithium, demeclocycline), metabolic disorders (hypercalcaemia, hypokalaemia), obstruction, vascular issues, granulomas, tumours, and infiltration.

Dipsogenic: Inappropriate thirst, head trauma, brain diseases.

Increased placental vasopressinase activity.

Psychogenic: Psychiatric conditions, compulsive water drinking.

Genetic: Mutations in the AVP–neurophysin II or WFS1 genes.

 

Genetic: Mutations in the V2 receptor or aquaporin-2 genes.

Iatrogenic: Belief in the health benefits of excessive water intake.

Basal Plasma AVP

Low or undetectable (<1 pg/mL).

Normal or elevated (>1 pg/mL).

Low due to suppression by excessive water intake.

Low due to increased degradation.

Urine Osmolarity

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Low (<280 mOsm/L) but can temporarily concentrate with fluid deprivation.

Low (<280 mOsm/L).

Plasma Osmolarity

Increased

Increased

Decreased

Increased

Fluid Deprivation Test
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection increases urine osmolarity in severe CDI.
  • Urine does not concentrate.
  • AVP or desmopressin injection does not affect severe NDI.

Plasma osmolarity and sodium increase above normal without urine concentration.

Not typically performed during pregnancy.

MRI

Posterior pituitary bright spot absent or small.

The posterior pituitary bright- spot may be faint or absent.

Posterior pituitary bright spot present.

Not routinely used for diagnosis.

Desmopressin (DDAVP) Trial

Abolishes polyuria and polydipsia; reduces plasma osmolarity/sodium.

No effect on urine output, fluid intake, or plasma osmolarity/sodium.

Eliminates polyuria but not polydipsia, leading to hyponatremia.

Effective in controlling symptoms.

Plasma Copeptin

Low or undetectable.

It may be normal or elevated.

Suppressed due to low AVP.

It may be low due to AVP degradation.

Treatment

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Thiazide diuretics, amiloride, low-sodium diet, prostaglandin inhibitors.

Behavioural therapy, education about overhydration.

Desmopressin (DDAVP).

Resolution
  • Lifelong treatment is usually needed for acquired CDI
  • Genetic forms may improve.
  • Dependent on the underlying cause
  • Lithium-induced NDI may persist.
  • Dependent on behavioural modification and addressing the underlying cause.
  • Usually, it resolves after delivery.

 

In mannitol infusion (Option D), the urine osmolality is >300 mOsm/L.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with headache and cola-colored urine. His parents report throat pain 2 weeks ago. On examination, red blood cells are present in urine and his KFT is increased two fold. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis. This condition typically occurs after an infection, most commonly caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococcus. The diagnosis is supported by the classic presentation of cola-colored urine and recent history of throat infection. The condition develops due to formation of immune complexes by streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin B (SPEB), which get distributed in renal parenchyma and damage blood vessels, leading to increased protein excretion and hematuria.

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)

Cause

Group A β-Hemolytic streptococci

Pathogenesis

Immune-complex mediated (Type III hypersensitivity reaction)

Clinical manifestations
  • It is more common in children and young adults.
  • History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks).
  • Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain)
  • Periorbital and pedal oedema
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy:
    • Abrupt rise in BP
    • Headache
    • Loss of consciousness
  • Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting.

Test for antibodies
  • Anti- DNAse
  • Anti-Hyaluronidase
  • ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer

Lab findings

  • Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark (cola-colored) on standing (hematuria).
  • Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc).
  • Raised serum potassium
  • Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50
  • Normal serum C4 level.

Pathological findings
  • Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys

 

  • Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells).

 

  • Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition)

 

  • Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition).

Management

  • Self-limiting disorder
  • Conservative and supportive management involves:
    • HTN crisis: Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside
    • Pulmonary edema: Furosemide
    • Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin)
    • Dialysis if needed

 

Minimal change disease (Option A) is characterized by minimal changes in the glomeruli on microscopic examination and commonly presents in children with proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. The absence of significant proteinuria and presence of hematuria rules out this diagnosis.

Membranous Glomerulonephritis (Option B) typically presents with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposits, causing proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia. The acute onset and recent history of throat infection makes this diagnosis less likely.

IgA nephropathy (Option D) is characterized by IgA deposits in the mesangium and typically develops within 48 hours after an upper respiratory tract infection. The timing of symptoms (2 weeks after throat pain) and the classic cola-colored urine presentation makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used classify—
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

  • Acute kidney injury This option is correct. AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and diagnose acute kidney injury. These criteria consider changes in serum creatinine levels, urine output, and the time frame in which these changes occur to determine the severity of acute kidney injury.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Chronic renal failure This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify chronic renal failure. Chronic renal failure is a progressive, long-term condition characterized by a permanent loss of kidney function over time. It is usually diagnosed and classified based on the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and the presence of kidney damage lasting for at least three months.

Option C. Acute glomerulonephritis This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify acute glomerulonephritis. Acute glomerulonephritis refers to the inflammation and damage of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It is typically diagnosed through clinical symptoms, laboratory tests, and kidney biopsies.

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of symptoms characterized by increased proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. It is usually diagnosed based on clinical findings, urine tests, and blood tests.

questions.text: In the ICU, a patient experiencing renal failure presents with vomiting. Analysis of arterial blood gases reveals a pH level of 7.4, sodium (Na+) concentration of 140 mEq/L, chloride (CI-) concentration of 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate (HCO3-) concentration of 24 mEq/L, and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 40 mmHg. What metabolic abnormality is most likely occurring?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C.

  •  High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. The low sodium level suggests hyponatremia, which is associated with metabolic alkalosis. The elevated anion gap indicates the presence of a metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure or other underlying causes
    • Let's analyze the given ABG values:
    • pH: 7.4 (within the normal range, indicating no primary acid-base disturbance)
    • Na+: 140 mEq/L (low)
    • Cl-: 100 mEq/L (within the normal range)
    • HCO3-: 24 mEq/L (within the normal range)
    • PaCO2: 40 mmHg (within the normal range)
    • From these values, we can determine the likely metabolic abnormality. The low sodium (Na+) level suggests hyponatremia, which can occur in patients with renal failure. In this case, the patient has a concurrent high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Normal ABG: This option is incorrect because there is evidence of an abnormality in the ABG analysis (low sodium level).

Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: This option is incorrect because the anion gap is elevated in this case. The normal anion gap is associated with a chloride-based metabolic acidosis, which is not present here.

Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This option is incorrect because there is evidence of a metabolic acidosis in the ABG analysis (elevated anion gap).

questions.text: All the following are features of polycystic disease of kidneys except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Erythrocytosis: 

  • Erythrocytosis refers to an elevated red blood cell count. While it is not a typical feature of PKD, in some cases, PKD can lead to the development of renal cell carcinoma, which may cause erythrocytosis as a paraneoplastic syndrome. However, this is not a common finding in most cases of PKD.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Hematuria: Hematuria, which is the presence of blood in the urine, can occur in PKD due to the rupture or bleeding within the cysts. It is a common symptom of PKD.

Option B - Hypertension: High blood pressure is a common feature of PKD. The cysts in the kidneys can interfere with normal kidney function, leading to increased renin secretion and subsequent hypertension.

Option C - Renal Failure: PKD is a progressive condition that can eventually lead to kidney failure. The numerous cysts gradually replace the healthy kidney tissue, impairing kidney function over time.

questions.text: What is the probable reason for the quadriparesis developed by a 60-year-old patient after being treated with a significant amount of hypertonic fluids for 24 hours following a history of hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C. 

  • In the given scenario, the patient presented with hyponatremia and was treated with a large volume of hypertonic fluids over a short period of time. Following this treatment, the patient developed quadriparesis. These findings are suggestive of central pontine myelinolysis (Choice C).
  • Central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) is a condition characterized by the destruction of the myelin sheath in the central portion of the pons, which is a part of the brainstem. It is typically associated with rapid correction of hyponatremia, especially when the correction occurs too quickly. In this case, the hypertonic fluids caused a rapid increase in serum sodium levels, leading to osmotic changes in the brain and subsequent damage to the myelin sheath in the pons.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Brain infarct: Brain infarct (Choice A) refers to the obstruction of blood flow to a specific area of the brain, resulting in tissue damage. While hyponatremia can contribute to the development of cerebral edema and increase the risk of brain infarction, the rapid correction of hyponatremia in this case is more consistent with CPM.

Option B. Brainstem injury: Brainstem injury (Choice B) can result from trauma or other causes and can lead to a range of neurological symptoms. However, the rapid development of quadriparesis following the treatment with hypertonic fluids suggests a more specific diagnosis of CPM.

Option D. Rare cause of hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to an elevated serum sodium level. In this case, the patient presented with hyponatremia and received hypertonic fluids, so the development of hypernatremia is not likely to be the cause of the patient's condition. Therefore, Choice D is an incorrect option.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with complaints of burning micturition. Prostatic examination was normal. Urinalysis shows >50 pus cells per high power field, but urine culture shows no growth. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Sterile pyuria

Explanation:

  • Sterile pyuria is defined as the presence of >10 WBCs/mm³ or >3 WBCs/HPF in unspun urine, or a positive dipstick for leukocyte esterase/nitrites, without significant bacteriuria (i.e., <10⁵ CFU/mL on culture).
  • It is the presence of pus cells in urine without bacterial growth on culture. It can result from non-bacterial infections (e.g., tuberculosis), inflammatory conditions, or prior antibiotic use. A normal prostate exam and no bacterial growth despite significant pyuria support this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Chronic bacterial prostatitis (Option A): Typically shows positive urine culture and may have prostatic tenderness.

Acute bacterial prostatitis (Option B): Presents with fever, painful prostate on DRE, and positive culture.

Granulomatous prostatitis (Option C): Rare, often associated with tuberculosis, would show prostatic abnormalities.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male presents with a complicated urinary tract infection and is found to be hypotensive. His blood pressure does not respond to intravenous fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibiotic to manage his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Meropenem

Explanation:

Meropenem is the most appropriate antibiotic for a diabetic patient in septic shock due to a complicated UTI, providing necessary broad-spectrum coverage, including for ESBL-producing organisms.

In the given scenario, the patient with a complicated UTI and septic shock is most likely infected with Pseudomonas or Klebsiella, for which the drug of choice is meropenem, a Carbapenem antibiotic.

  • MOA: Inhibits transpeptidase (penicillin-binding protein) and prevents cross-linking.
  • Drugs:
    • Imipenem
    • Meropenem
    • Faropenem
    • Doripenem
    • Ertapenem
  • Uses of carbapenems:
    • Used in nosocomial infections.
      • Meropenem is a reserve drug for the treatment of serious nosocomial infections like septicaemia, febrile neutropenia, intraabdominal and pelvic infections, etc., caused by cephalosporin-resistant bacteria and diabetic foot. (Option C)
    • DOC in
      • Acinetobacter baumannii (Ventilator-associated pneumonia)
      • Klebsiella
      • Burkholderia
      • Serratia
      • Proteus
      • Pseudomonas

Incorrect Options:

Amoxicillin-clavulanate (amoxiclav) (Option A) is ineffective for complicated UTIs with resistant Pseudomonas or ESBL-producing Klebsiella and is unsuitable for severe infections where meropenem is preferred.

Nitrofurantoin (Option B) is effective for uncomplicated lower UTIs but poorly penetrates blood and renal tissue, making it ineffective for complicated UTIs or septic shock. It also lacks activity against Pseudomonas and many Klebsiella strains in severe infections.

Ciprofloxacin (Option D) has broad activity, including against Pseudomonas, but rising resistance in hospital settings limits its use. It is not first-line for critically ill septic patients, where meropenem is preferred.

questions.text: A patient with RTA is passing red color urine due to myoglobinuria. Which of the following will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Hyperkalemia:

Explanation:

  • Myoglobinuria typically occurs after rhabdomyolysis, where muscle breakdown releases myoglobin and intracellular potassium into the bloodstream.
  • Myoglobin is nephrotoxic, causing acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
  • Tubular injury in ATN often impairs potassium excretion, resulting in Type 4 RTA physiology, which is characterized by hyperkalemia and mild metabolic acidosis.
  • The potassium rise is further exacerbated by direct release from damaged muscle cells.

Incorrect Options:

Hypernatremia (Option A): Less common in ATN; if anything, sodium tends to be low due to renal losses and fluid shifts.

Hyponatremia (Option C): Can occur in kidney injury but not a hallmark feature of RTA with rhabdomyolysis.

Hypokalemia (Option D): Seen in Type 1 (distal) and Type 2 (proximal) RTA, but not in Type 4 RTA or ATN — here potassium retention predominates.

questions.text: A patient after RTA had a renal shut down. Work-up shows: FeNa: < 1%, Urine osmolality: 300 mOsm/kg, Urinary sodium: 40 mEq/L. Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute Tubular Necrosis (ATN):

Explanation:

  • This presentation points to intrinsic renal injury, specifically ATN, where damaged renal tubules lose the ability to reabsorb sodium and concentrate urine.
  • Key features in this case:
    • Urinary sodium > 40 mEq/L → tubular sodium wasting
    • Urine osmolality ~300 mOsm/kg → isosthenuria (urine similar to plasma)
    • FeNa < 1% is more typical of pre-renal AKI, but in early ATN or mixed states it can also be low.
    • Here, the high urinary sodium and poor urine concentration outweigh FeNa alone, supporting ATN.

Clinical Phases of ATN

Phase

Description

Prerenal Phase (Pre-ATN)
  • ↓ Renal perfusion (e.g., hypovolemia, CHF)
  • Tubular function intact
  • FeNa <1%, BUN:Cr >20
  • Responds to fluids
  • Reversible if corrected early

Initiation Phase
  • Time of original injury (ischemia/toxins)
  • Mild ↓ GFR, slight ↑ creatinine
  • Urine output may be normal
  • Damage beginning but potentially reversible

Extension Phase

  • Ongoing injury + inflammation (days 1–3)
  • Tubular necrosis, obstruction
  • Key sign: ↑ Creatinine + new oliguria despite fluids
  • FeNa >2%, granular casts may appear

Maintenance Phase
  • Established tubular damage
  • Low GFR, sustained ↑ creatinine/BUN
  • Oliguric or non-oliguric
  • Electrolyte imbalances: hyperkalemia, acidosis

Recovery (Repair) Phase
  • Tubular regeneration
  • Polyuric phase: ↑ urine output
  • Gradual ↓ creatinine
  • Risk: volume depletion, electrolyte loss

 

Incorrect Options:

Pre-renal AKI (Option B):

  • Characterized by low urinary sodium (<20 mEq/L) and high urine osmolality (>500 mOsm/kg).

Post-renal AKI (Option C):

  • Labs are variable; diagnosis usually requires imaging evidence of obstruction.

Renal AKI (Option D):

  • Too broad; ATN is the specific intrinsic renal diagnosis here.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with chronic kidney disease presents with complaints of increasing fatigue, dyspnea on exertion, and signs of congestive heart failure. On evaluation, he is found to have anemia. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Darbepoetin alfa

Explanation: Anemia in chronic kidney disease is primarily due to decreased erythropoietin production by the kidneys. In a CKD patient with symptomatic anemia (after ruling out and/or correcting iron deficiency), the most appropriate next step is to start an erythropoiesis-stimulating agent (ESA) such as darbepoetin alfa or epoetin alfa.

  • This improves hemoglobin levels, exercise tolerance, and quality of life, and reduces transfusion needs.

Oral iron therapy (Option A): Useful if there is iron deficiency; however, in CKD-related anemia without iron deficiency, it will not correct the problem.

Intravenous iron infusion (Option B): Indicated if iron deficiency is documented or oral iron is not tolerated; not the first step if iron stores are adequate.

Blood transfusion (Option C): Reserved for severe, symptomatic anemia or when rapid correction is required; frequent use increases risk of volume overload and alloimmunization.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely condition responsible for a 35-year-old male experiencing nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting, with ABG results indicating pH of 7.55, PCO2 of 50 mmHg, and HCO3- of 44 mmol?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • Given that all three parameters are moving in the same direction, indicating a metabolic disorder, and with an increase in pH, the condition is likely metabolic alkalosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B & C are correct.

questions.text: As per KDIGO, which of the following falls under G3b?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 30-44

 

Explanation:

  • This range corresponds to Stage 3b of CKD, which is classified as a moderate to severe decrease in kidney function, with GFR between 30-44 mL/min/1.73m².

According to the Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) classification for chronic kidney disease (CKD):

  1. GFR: A GFR of 50 mL/min falls into Stage 3 CKD (G3a), defined as 30–59 mL/min.
  2. Albuminuria: An albuminuria level of 12 mg/g is categorised as A1 (normal to mildly increased), which is <30 mg/g.

Combining these classifications:

  • GFR Stage: G3a (Stage 3)
  • Albuminuria Category: A1

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with hematuria. Which of the following are seen in glomerular hematuria?

 

Statements:


	Brown-colored urine
	Dysuria absent
	Crystals present
	Edema rare
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

Glomerular hematuria presents with brown-colored urine due to RBC breakdown, absence of dysuria as it is not due to lower urinary tract infection, and edema may occur in nephritic syndrome, but is not rare; however, crystals are not a feature of glomerular hematuria.

 

Glomerular Hematuria

Glomerular hematuria occurs due to damage to the glomerular filtration barrier, leading to the leakage of red blood cells (RBCs) into the urine.

 

Causes:

  • Glomerulonephritis (Post-streptococcal, IgA nephropathy, lupus nephritis, membranoproliferative GN)
  • Small Vessel Vasculitis (ANCA-associated vasculitis, Goodpasture’s syndrome)
  • Hereditary Conditions (Alport syndrome, Thin basement membrane disease)

 

Features

  • Color: Cola-colored or smoky brown urine
  • Dysmorphic RBCs (acanthocytes, Mickey Mouse cells)
  • Proteinuria: Often present, especially if associated with nephritic syndrome
  • Presence of RBC casts (diagnostic of glomerular origin)
  • Clots absent (distinguishes from non-glomerular hematuria)

 

Serum Markers: Often associated with increased serum creatinine.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children?
questions.solution:
Steroids are the first-line treatment for nephrotic syndrome, particularly in minimal change disease, which is the most common cause in children. Corticosteroids work by reducing inflammation and suppressing the immune response that leads to proteinuria. The typical initial treatment consists of oral prednisone, with most patients showing a response within 4-8 weeks of therapy.

 

Feature

Steroid-Responsive Nephrotic Syndrome

Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome

Definition

Nephrotic syndrome that responds well to corticosteroid treatment.

Nephrotic syndrome that does not improve despite adequate corticosteroid treatment (e.g., prednisolone at 2 mg/kg/day for 6 weeks).

Types:

  • Initial Steroid Resistance: Lack of response from the onset.
  • Late Steroid Resistance: Resistance develops after initial response.

Common Type

Minimal Change Nephrotic Syndrome (MCNS) accounts for about 80% of cases in children.

It is often associated with Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) or genetic mutations affecting podocytes.

Diagnosis

Diagnosed without kidney biopsy; characterised by heavy proteinuria, low serum albumin, and no significant glomerular damage.

Further investigation (e.g., kidney biopsy) is required to determine the underlying cause.

Management

Responds to high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone), leading to remission of proteinuria and oedema within 10-14 days.

Treatment may include immunosuppressive agents, calcineurin inhibitors, or other therapies, as corticosteroids are often ineffective.

 

Steroids and cyclophosphamide (Option B): While this combination may be used in steroid-resistant cases or specific types of nephrotic syndrome, it is not the first-line treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children, which is mainly due to Minimal change disease. The addition of cyclophosphamide is reserved for cases that fail to respond to steroids alone or have frequent relapses. Also, the potential toxicity of cyclophosphamide makes it unsuitable as an initial therapy.

 

Cyclophosphamide (Option C): Using cyclophosphamide alone is not the recommended initial treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children. It is typically used as a second-line agent in steroid-resistant cases or specific pathological variants.


ACE inhibitors (Option D): While ACE inhibitors can help reduce proteinuria and are often used as adjunctive therapy, they are not the primary treatment for nephrotic syndrome. They are typically used in conjunction with immunosuppressive therapy, which is the mainstay for treating the underlying cause of nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine follow-up. Her serum creatinine and potassium levels are normal, but she has microalbuminuria and an HbA1c of 8%. Her blood pressure and pulse are within normal limits, and she is currently on metformin for diabetes management. What should be the next step in her management?

choices.text: Stop Metformin and start a different OHA

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Start an ACE inhibitor.

 

Explanation:

Starting ACE inhibitors early in the progression of diabetic nephropathy, particularly with the presence of microalbuminuria, has demonstrated significant benefits in reducing the risk of kidney failure and cardiovascular events.

 

Management of Diabetic nephropathy

Oral Hypoglycemic agents (OHAs)
  • SGLT2 inhibitors lower the risk of cardiovascular events and renal failure; they are also recently approved for HFpEF.
  • For HbA1C < 9.5%, OHAs can be used
  • Metformin is withheld if eGFR is < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (Option C), and drugs safe in renal failure can be used like
    • Glipizide
    • Linagliptin
    • Repaglinide

Insulin

80% of the calculated dose is started if HbA1C > 9.5% (Option B)

Antihypertensives
  • In the presence of microalbuminuria, ACEi and ARBs have shown evidence to slow the progression of nephropathy if started in early stages.
  • In hypertension, for BP > 130/90, ACEi or ARBs are preferred
  • If BP is still not under control, Calcium channel blocker (CCB) can be added
  • Thiazide diuretic - in the presence of oedema (Option A)
  • If eGFR <30 ml/min, then the diuretic used - Metolazone.
  • ACEi/ARB comes with a side effect of hyperkalemia; hence, regular monitoring of potassium is necessary.
  • In the presence of hyperkalemia, ACEi/ARB is replaced by CCB
  • Alpha blocker (Prazosin) - hyperkalemia in ESRD.

For Hyperkalemia

K Binding resins (Bind to potassium in the gastrointestinal tract and promote its excretion)

  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate
  • Patiromer
  • Sodium zirconate

Renal Transplant

If eGFR is < 20 mL/min/1.73m2.

questions.text:
Which of the following is most likely based on the lab values given?


	Blood pH: 7.3 (indicating mild acidosis)
	Sodium (Na+): 134 mEq/L (mildly decreased)
	Potassium (K+): 2.8 mEq/L (hypokalemia)
	Chloride (Cl-): 113 mEq/L (elevated)
	Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻): 12 mEq/L (low, indicating metabolic acidosis)
	Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN): 3 mg/dL (low-normal)
	Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL (normal)
	Urinary pH: 9.4 (alkaline)
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - RTA Type 1 (Distal RTA):

  • RTA Type 1, also known as distal RTA, is characterized by the inability of the distal tubules of the kidneys to excrete hydrogen ions, leading to an alkaline urinary pH (usually >5.5). Patients typically have a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypokalemia (low potassium), and a low serum bicarbonate level. In this case, the blood pH is mildly acidotic (7.3), with a low HCO₃⁻ (12 mEq/L) and hypokalemia (K+ of 2.8 mEq/L). The urine pH is markedly alkaline (9.4), which is consistent with RTA Type 1.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - RTA Type 2 (Proximal RTA): RTA Type 2, or proximal RTA, involves a defect in bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubule, leading to a loss of bicarbonate in the urine and subsequent metabolic acidosis. Urine is typically acidic (pH < 5.5) after the loss of bicarbonate is maximized. Patients can have hypokalemia, but the urinary pH would not remain as high (9.4) after the plasma bicarbonate is depleted, making this less likely.

Option C - RTA Type 4: RTA Type 4 is characterized by hyperkalemia (high potassium) and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This type results from hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance. In this case, the patient has hypokalemia (K+ of 2.8 mEq/L), not hyperkalemia, making RTA Type 4 an unlikely diagnosis.

Option D - High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA): HAGMA is characterized by a high anion gap due to the accumulation of unmeasured anions (e.g., lactate, ketoacids, toxins). The calculated anion gap here is normal (AG = Na - [Cl + HCO₃] = 134 - [113 + 12] = 9), which does not support a diagnosis of HAGMA. Therefore, HAGMA is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A patient having hypertension is on thiazides and is complaining of fatigue and hypokalemia. Which of the following drugs can prevent potassium loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Amiloride

Explanation:

  • Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that acts by inhibiting the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the distal nephron. When used in combination with thiazide diuretics, it helps prevent hypokalemia while maintaining Thiazide’s antihypertensive efficacy. This combination approach is particularly useful in patients experiencing thiazide-induced hypokalemia.
  • Amiloride works as a weak antihypertensive but is valuable for its potassium-sparing properties, though it should be used cautiously in patients with renal failure or hyperkalemia.

Classification of Diuretics :

Type

Mechanism of action

Examples

Clinical uses

Side effects
  1. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

Inhibit carbonic anhydrase enzyme in the proximal tubule, decreasing bicarbonate reabsorption

Acetazolamide, Methazolamide

Glaucoma, Altitude sickness

Metabolic acidosis, Hypokalemia
  1. Loop diuretics

Inhibit the Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle

Furosemide, Bumetanide

Acute pulmonary edema, Chronic heart failure, Hypercalcemia

Hypokalemia, Ototoxicity, Metabolic alkalosis,

Hyperglycemia,

Hyperuricemia

 
  1. Thiazide diuretics

Inhibit sodium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule

Hydrochlorothiazide, Chlorthalidone

Hypertension, Edema

Hypokalemia, Hyponatremia,

Hyperglycemia

Hyperuricemia
  1. Potassium-sparing

Inhibit sodium channels in the distal nephron or block aldosterone receptors

Spironolactone, Amiloride

Heart failure, Hyperaldosteronism

Hyperkalemia, Gynecomastia (for Spironolactone)
  1. Osmotic diuretics

Increase osmolarity of the glomerular filtrate, inhibiting water reabsorption.

Mannitol, Glycerin

Cerebral oedema, Acute glaucoma

Dehydration, Electrolyte imbalance

 

Furosemide (Option A): This is a loop diuretic that actually increases potassium excretion and can worsen hypokalemia. It is primarily used in patients with reduced GFR, CHF, or conditions requiring significant sodium excretion.

Acetazolamide (Option C): This carbonic anhydrase inhibitor is mainly used for treating glaucoma, altitude sickness, and periodic paralysis. It does not prevent potassium loss and can actually contribute to electrolyte imbalances.

Indapamide (Option D): This thiazide-like diuretic, similar to traditional thiazides, can cause potassium depletion and would not help prevent hypokalemia. It shares the same mechanism of action and side effect profile as other thiazide diuretics.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child with a history of GTCS came with an episode of convulsions for more than 45 minutes. What will be the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lorazepam followed by levetiracetam

Explanation:

  • Status epilepticus (SE) is defined as continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness lasting more than 30 minutes.

They are generally of 2 types:

  • Generalized convulsive status epilepticus (GCSE)
    • GCSE is an emergency and must be treated immediately (e.g., persistent, generalized electrographic seizures, coma, and tonic-clonic movements).
  • Nonconvulsive status epilepticus (NCSE)
    • E.g., persistent absence seizures or focal seizures with confusion or partially impaired consciousness, and minimal motor abnormalities.

In the case of impending and early SE, the standard protocol involves administering IV lorazepam 0.1 mg/kg followed by levetiracetam 20-30 mg/kg.

For established and early refractory SE, the treatment progresses to Propofol 2 mg/kg IV followed by 2-10 mg/kg/hr with the addition of anticonvulsants like levetiracetam.

Management of Status Epilepticus:

Valproate followed by gabapentin (Option B): While valproate can be used in the treatment of GTCS, this combination is not the standard first-line treatment for status epilepticus. Gabapentin is typically used for chronic seizure management rather than acute status epilepticus.

Carbamazepine followed by lorazepam (Option C): Carbamazepine is primarily used in the treatment of partial or focal seizures and is not appropriate for acute status epilepticus. Additionally, benzodiazepines should be administered first in status epilepticus, not after other anticonvulsants.

Levetiracetam followed by valproate (Option D): This sequence is incorrect as benzodiazepines (lorazepam) should be the first-line treatment in early status epilepticus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. Lab investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be signs of underlying dyselectrolytemia except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cerebral edema: 

  • The given scenario points towards hypokalemia. Cerebral edema is related to fluctuations in the value of sodium (hyponatremia). Potassium does not play a role in plasma osmolality hence do not cause cerebral edema.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can contribute to the development of Torsades de Pointes a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Option B - Quadriplegia: Hypokalemia causes excessive hyperpolarization in skeletal muscles, impairing their ability to contract and leading to weakness and potential paralysis.

Option C - Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemic polyuria results from both excessive drinking (central polydipsia) and the kidneys' reduced response to antidiuretic hormone (AVP-resistant renal concentrating defect).

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)?

choices.text: Patient can be clinically euvolemic to hypervolemic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

  • In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically > 40 mEq/L, not < 20 mEq/L, due to volume expansion and natriuresis.

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

Definition

Excessive ADH release leading to impaired water excretion and hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. (Option D)

Etiology
  • CNS disturbances: Stroke, infection, subarachnoid hemorrhage, etc.
  • Malignancies: Small cell lung cancer (most common), other cancers.
  • Drugs: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, SSRIs, "Ecstasy", NSAIDs, etc.
  • Surgery: Pain-induced ADH hypersecretion.
  • Pulmonary diseases: Pneumonia (Option A ruled out), respiratory failure, etc.
  • Hormone deficiency: Hypopituitarism, hypothyroidism.
  • HIV: Associated with infections.
  • Hereditary SIADH: V2 receptor mutation.

Pathophysiology
  • ADH function: Regulates water balance by controlling plasma osmolality; excess ADH causes water retention, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Volume regulation: In hypovolemia, ADH release is driven by volume receptors, worsening hyponatremia.

Clinical Presentation
  • Acute hyponatremia: Nausea, vomiting, headache, seizures, coma.
  • Chronic hyponatremia: Nonspecific symptoms (nausea, confusion, falls in elderly).

Diagnosis

Schwartz and Bartter Criteria:

  • Serum sodium <135 mEq/L (Option B)
  • Serum osmolality <275 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium >40 mEq/L
  • Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg (Option C)
  • The absence of clinical evidence of volume depletion (like normal skin turgor, blood pressure within the reference range)
  • The absence of hyponatremia due to other causes (like adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, cardiac failure, pituitary insufficiency, renal disease with salt wastage, hepatic disease, drugs that impair renal water excretion.)

Tests:

  • Renal function, serum osmolality, cortisol levels, thyroid tests, imaging for underlying causes.

Management
  • Fluid restriction: For mild to moderate symptoms.
  • Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, with careful correction rate (<8 mEq/L in 24 hrs).
  • Medications:
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Conivaptan, Tolvaptan)
    • Other: Loop diuretics, salt tablets, demeclocycline, lithium.

Complications
  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome: Risk from rapid sodium correction.
  • Severe hyponatremia: Can lead to seizures, coma, and death in acute cases.

questions.text:
"Which of the following best characterizes the acid-base status of a 45-year-old diabetic patient presenting to the emergency department with abdominal pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia, whose arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following:

pH: 7.34

Sodium (Na): 135

Potassium (K): 5

Bicarbonate (HCO3): 12

Chloride (Cl): 92

RBS = 450 mg/dl
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA): 

  • The pH and bicarbonate levels are reduced hence it indicates metabolic acidosis.
  • Formula for Anion gap = [Na+] - [Cl- + HCO3- ]
  • In this scenario, Anion gap = 135 - [92 + 12] = 31
  • Therefore, the anion gap is >12 mEq/L which indicates a High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

 

Incorrect  Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of chronic bipedal edema?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chronic venous insufficiency: 

  • Chronic venous insufficiency typically presents with unilateral pedal edema rather than bilateral. The edema, often pitting, can be limited to the ankles, extend upwards to the knees, or even involve the thighs in severe instances. With progression, the edema may transition from being primarily pitting to becoming more indurated over time.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chronic liver disease: In chronic liver disease (CLD), decreased albumin levels result in reduced oncotic pressure, contributing to the development of bipedal edema.

Option B - Nephrotic syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome also leads to bipedal edema by lowering oncotic pressure due to decreased albumin levels.

Option D - Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis results in bipedal edema due to the presence of hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: A young patient developed hyperpigmentation of distal fingers after being hospitalized post-adrenalectomy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Nelson syndrome

  • Nelson syndrome is a rare condition that occurs in patients who have had both adrenal glands removed (bilateral adrenalectomy) as a treatment for Cushing's disease.
  • The hyperpigmentation of distal fingers post-adrenalectomy is due to the development of pituitary adenoma that produces excess adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), especially in areas exposed to friction and pressure, such as the distal fingers.

Nelson syndrome/post-adrenalectomy syndrome

Definition

Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH. Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess.

Prevention

Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumours
  • Headache
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones

Evaluation

  • Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels:
    • Very high levels.
    • Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones.
  • Brain MRI shows pituitary tumours or enlargement of existing tumours.
  • Screening:
    • Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy.

Management

  • Surgical Removal of the Tumor
  • Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery
  • Medical Treatment
  • Hormonal Replacement Therapy

Addison's disease (Option A) involves primary adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones. Hyperpigmentation can occur due to increased ACTH levels, but Addison's disease is typically associated with adrenal atrophy or autoimmune destruction, not post-adrenalectomy.

Conn's syndrome (Option B), or primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by excessive production of aldosterone by the adrenal glands. It does not typically cause hyperpigmentation. Symptoms are usually related to hypertension and hypokalemia.

Cushing syndrome (Option D) is caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It usually leads to symptoms such as central obesity, moon face, and purple striae, rather than hyperpigmentation of the fingers.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Calcium oxalate

Explanation: The given image showing an envelope or dumbbell shape under the microscope is characteristic of calcium oxalate crystals.
