questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Liddle syndrome

Explanation: Liddle syndrome is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension.

 

Renal Tubular Syndromes

Defect

Seen in

Cause

Effects

Fanconi Syndrome

Generalised reabsorption defect in PCT

Childhood
  • Hereditary defects (wilson disease, tyrosinemia, glycogen storage disease, cystinosis)
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Ischemia
  • Nephrotoxic drugs (ifosfamide, cisplatin, tenofovir, expired tetracycline)
  • Lead poisoning
  • Metabolic acidosis (proximal RTA)
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Phosphaturia
  • Osteopenia

Gitelman Syndrome (Option C)

  • Reabsorptive defect of NaCl- in DCT.
  • Mimics chronic thiazide diuretic use.

Late childhood or adulthood

Autosomal recessive
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypocalciuria

Bartter Syndrome (Option A)
  • Reabsorptive defect in thick ascending loop of Henle.
  • Affects Na+/K+/2Cl- cotransporter.
  • Mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Childhood

Autosomal recessive
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Hyperchloremia

Liddle Syndrome

Gain of function mutation → ↑ Na+ reabsorption in collecting tubules (↑ activity of Na+ channel)

 

Childhood

Autosomal dominant
  • Hypertension
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Hypoaldosteronism

 

Gordon syndrome (Option D) (also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism type II) is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that presents with hypertension, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis, rather than the hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria is used for classification of which of the folowing coditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acute kidney injury

Explanation:

  • The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and stage acute kidney injury (AKI). These criteria help healthcare professionals assess the severity of AKI and guide treatment decisions.

↑ SCr × 1.5 or ↓ GFR > 25%

< 0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours

Injury

↑ SCr × 2 or ↓ GFR > 50%

< 0.5 mL/kg/h for 12 hours

Failure

↑ SCr × 3 or ↓ GFR > 75%

or

Baseline SCr ≥ 353.6 μmol/L (≥ 4 mg/dL) +

↑ SCr > 44.2 μmol/L (> 0.5 mg/dL)

< 0.3 mL/kg/h for 24 hours

or

Anuria for 12 hours

Loss of Kidney Function

-

End-Stage Kidney Disease

questions.text: In methanol intoxication, which of the subsequent electrolyte abnormalities is observed?

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with high anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic alkalosis with normal anion gap

questions.solution:
• Methanol intoxication leads to the formation of toxic metabolites, including formic acid, which causes metabolic acidosis. The acidosis results from the accumulation of formic acid and its metabolites, leading to an increased anion gap. (Options A, C and D ruled out)
  • Other causes
  • Ketoacidosis
  • Uremia
  • Lactic acidosis

questions.text: What is the most probable cause of the muteness, quadriplegia, and rigidity observed in an elderly female patient who had a previous medical history of severe vomiting and was aggressively treated for severe dehydration at a different hospital one week ago?
questions.solution:
Muteness, quadriplegia, and rigidity after treatment for dehydration in an elderly patient strongly suggest osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS) due to rapid correction of hyponatremia.
• Rapid sodium correction causes demyelination in the central pons (central pontine myelinolysis), leading to features like "locked-in syndrome", rigidity, and pseudobulbar palsy.
• History of severe vomiting and dehydration likely led to hyponatremia, which was overcorrected.

Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM) / Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome

Feature Description
Etiology Rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia
Common in Alcoholics, malnourished, post-liver transplant
Neurological features Dysarthria, mutism, quadriplegia, pseudobulbar palsy
Imaging MRI shows symmetric lesions in central pons
Prevention Limit sodium correction to ≤8–10 mEq/L in 24 hrs

Malignant hyperthermia (Option A):
Incorrect because it occurs due to anesthetic agents (like succinylcholine or halothane) and presents with hyperthermia, rigidity, acidosis—not mutism or quadriplegia without fever.

Severe catatonia (Option B):
Incorrect because catatonia may explain mutism and rigidity but not quadriplegia. It is also not linked to sodium correction.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (Option D):
Incorrect because NMS occurs after neuroleptic use and features hyperthermia, lead-pipe rigidity, and altered mental status—not quadriplegia or locked-in features.

questions.text: An increased anion gap is seen in:
questions.solution: An increased anion gap is seen in Metabolic acidosis. It occurs when there is an excess of acid or a loss of bicarbonate (HCO3-) in the body, leading to a decrease in the bicarbonate concentration and a decrease in pH. This decrease is compensated by an increase in chloride ions, resulting in an increased anion gap. (Options A, B and D ruled out)

questions.text: All of the following aid in the localization of the lesion to the spinal cord except?

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.solution:
Contralateral hemiplegia refers to weakness or paralysis affecting one side of the body that is opposite to the side of the lesion. However, contralateral hemiplegia is not characteristic of lesions within the spinal cord. It is more commonly associated with brainstem lesions.

 

Fasciculation at the level of the lesion (Option B) is observed at the uppermost level of the lesion in the spinal cord; it can provide clues about the involvement of the corresponding spinal cord segment.

 

UMN lesions (Option C) involve the descending motor pathways (corticospinal) originating from the brain and traveling through the spinal cord, while LMN (Option C) lesions affect the peripheral nerves or nerve roots exiting the spinal cord.

 

Bladder involvement (Option D), such as urinary retention or incontinence, can indicate dysfunction or damage to the nerves controlling bladder function within the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which one of the following medications is not employed for the urgent (immediate) treatment of hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is not typically used for the immediate management of hyperkalemia. It may be used in certain situations, such as if the patient has concurrent magnesium deficiency, which can contribute to electrolyte imbalances. However, it is not the primary drug of choice for immediate intervention in hyperkalemia.

 

Calcium gluconate (Option A) is commonly used in the emergency management of hyperkalaemia. It helps stabilise the cardiac membrane and counteracts the effects of elevated potassium levels on the heart.

 

Salbutamol (Option B), a beta-2 agonist, is frequently used for the immediate management of hyperkalaemia. It promotes the cellular uptake of potassium, effectively lowering its concentration in the blood.

 

Insulin (Option C), often administered with dextrose, is a key component of emergency hyperkalaemia management. Insulin drives potassium from the bloodstream into the cells, reducing serum potassium levels.

questions.text: A patient with hyperkalemia and elevated urea levels underwent dialysis. Towards the end of the session, she became drowsy and had a sudden seizure episode. On examination, the patient was hypotensive. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - IV Mannitol:

  • The given scenario is suggestive of the dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) or the reverse urea effect.
  • Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome (DDS) is an acute neurological complication, often seen in patients undergoing their first hemodialysis session. It results from the rapid removal of urea and solutes, creating an osmotic gradient between the blood and brain interstitial fluid. This gradient causes water to shift into brain cells, leading to cerebral edema.

Features:

Symptoms: Headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, restlessness, confusion, muscle cramps, tremors, and in severe cases, seizures or coma.

Risk Factors: First hemodialysis session, high blood urea nitrogen (BUN >175 mg/dL), children, elderly, rapid dialysis, and pre-existing neurological conditions.

Management:

  • Modify dialysis parameters to reduce urea removal rates.
  • Administer osmotic agents like mannitol to reduce cerebral edema.
  • Provide supportive care for symptoms.

Prevention:

  • Initiate dialysis at a slower rate with shorter sessions.
  • Adjust dialysate composition, particularly sodium levels.
  • Avoid aggressive uremia correction, especially in high-risk patients.

Complications associated with Hemodialysis

During treatment

Between treatment
  • Hypotension: The most common acute complication during hemodialysis, especially in patients with diabetes mellitus.
  • Muscle cramps.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions: These reactions, particularly to the dialyser, are most common during its first use and are often associated with bio incompatible cellulosic-containing membranes.
  • Cardiac arrhythmias: D/t potassium & acid-base shifts.
  • Hemorrhage: D/t anticoagulation & venous needle disconnection.
  • Air embolism: D/t faulty lines & equipment malfunction.
  • Pulmonary oedema (D/t fluid overload).
  • Systemic sepsis: Usually involves vascular access devices (catheter or fistula).
  • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome typically occurs during or after a patient's first dialysis session. It presents with confusion, restlessness, headache, and muscle twitching. It is caused by a urea gradient between the CSF and blood that raises intracranial pressure.
  • Amyloidosis (D/t beta 2 microglobulin)
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome (due to amyloid deposition in the flexor retinaculum).
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Bumetanide (Option A): Bumetanide is a loop diuretic used to treat conditions like fluid overload or edema, but it is not indicated for the management of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome. It works by inhibiting sodium and chloride reabsorption in the kidney, and does not address the osmotic shifts causing cerebral edema in DDS.

Ethacrynic acid (Option B): Ethacrynic acid is another loop diuretic that can be used in conditions like edema, but it is not the first choice for treating DDS. It does not counteract the osmotic gradient responsible for cerebral edema during dialysis.

Nesiritide (Option C): Nesiritide is a recombinant form of B-type natriuretic peptide, used to treat acute decompensated heart failure. It does not address the underlying pathophysiology of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome, which involves osmotic shifts causing cerebral edema.

questions.text: 23 year old person with a history of flank Pain and fatigue and history of red coloured urine. On investigation there were more than 20 RBC/ hpf and microscopy showed dysmorphic RBC. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PSGN:

The symptoms described, including flank pain, fatigue, history of red-colored urine, and the presence of more than 20 red blood cells (RBCs) per high-power field (hpf) with dysmorphic RBCs on microscopy, are indicative of glomerular involvement, which points toward a kidney-related issue. Among the options provided, PSGN is the most likely diagnosis for several reasons:

  1. Hematuria (Presence of RBCs in urine): The patient's history of red-colored urine and the presence of more than 20 RBCs/hpf in the urine sample indicate hematuria, which is a hallmark of glomerular pathology.
  2. Dysmorphic RBCs: Dysmorphic RBCs in the urine are a characteristic feature of glomerular bleeding. These abnormally shaped RBCs are a result of mechanical damage as they pass through the damaged glomerular capillaries.
  3. Flank Pain and Fatigue: Flank pain and fatigue can be associated with glomerulonephritis due to impaired kidney function and inflammation.
  4. History of Red-Colored Urine: The history of red-colored urine, also known as hematuria, further supports the presence of glomerular involvement.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Minimal Change Disease: This is a form of nephrotic syndrome, characterized by massive proteinuria and minimal changes on light microscopy. It typically presents with proteinuria, edema, and normal to slightly elevated blood pressure. It doesn't usually cause gross hematuria or flank pain.

Option C - UTI (Urinary Tract Infection): While a UTI can cause hematuria, it is less likely to cause dysmorphic RBCs and would not explain the flank pain and fatigue.

Option D - Bladder Calculi: Bladder calculi (stones) might cause hematuria, but they would not explain the presence of dysmorphic RBCs, and typically, the pain associated with bladder stones is localized to the lower abdomen and not the flanks.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of pain in the flank region with hematuria. On investigation, an X-ray shows multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Renal calculi

  • The presence of flank pain, hematuria, and multiple calcifications seen on X-ray in both kidneys strongly suggests the presence of kidney stones.

Clinical manifestations of Renal stones:

  • Renal colic is typically characterised by severe, sharp, and fluctuating pain originating in the flank and radiating toward the lower abdomen or groin, based on the location of the stone within the ureter.
    • Upper ureteral stone: Pain radiates anteriorly.
    • Lower ureteral stone: Pain radiates to the ipsilateral groin or labium in females/testicles in males.
  • Hematuria is a common finding due to ureteral irritation and damage caused by the sharp edges of the stone.
  • Nausea and vomiting are frequently present due to the intensity of pain and reno-gastric reflex.

Investigations for renal calculi

  • Lab investigations:
    • Urine analysis (24-hour urine analysis) and blood tests should be conducted to assess serum levels of calcium, uric acid, phosphate, oxalate, and other relevant substances.
  • Radiological investigations:
    • Helical CT abdomen (non-contrast) is the investigation of choice (gold standard) to confirm the diagnosis and locate the stones.
    • Ultrasonography (abdomen, KUB) can also be done.
    • X-ray (KUB) can also reveal radio-opaque stones such as Lysine, uric acid, and xanthine.

Management of renal stones

Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis).
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm.
  • Uretrorenoscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

Parathyroid adenoma (Option A) refers to the enlargement of one or more of the parathyroid glands, which are responsible for regulating calcium levels in the body.

While Polycystic kidney disease (PKD) (Option C) can lead to kidney-related symptoms, such as flank pain and hematuria, the presence of multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys is not a typical feature of this condition.

While CKD (Option D) can lead to various complications, such as the formation of kidney stones, the presence of multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys on X-ray is not specific to CKD.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who has symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis, along with a 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters, a urine osmolarity of 260 mOsm/L, an ADH assay result of 0.8 pg/ml, and a brain MRI showing no bright spot on T1 weighted images?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -  Pituitary DI (diabetes insipidus)

  • The patient's presentation of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis along with a 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters and low urine osmolarity indicates the inability to concentrate urine, which is a characteristic feature of diabetes insipidus.
  • The low ADH (antidiuretic hormone) level detected by the assay suggests and absence of the bright spot on T1 weighted MRI is consistent with a lack of posterior pituitary gland hyperintensity, further supporting the diagnosis of pituitary DI.
  • In pituitary DI, the polyuria results in a small (1–2%) decrease in body water and a commensurate increase in plasma osmolarity and sodium that stimulates thirst and a compensatory increase in water intake.
  • As a result, hypernatremia and other overt physical or laboratory signs of dehydration do not develop unless the patient also has a defect in thirst or fails to increase fluid intake for some other reason.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nephrogenic DI: This statement is incorrect. Nephrogenic DI is characterized by impaired renal response to ADH, resulting in the inability to concentrate urine. 

Option B - Primary polydipsia: This statement is incorrect. Primary polydipsia refers to excessive water intake leading to water diuresis. 

Option D - Mannitol infusion: This statement is incorrect. Mannitol infusion, a diuretic agent, is used to increase urine output in specific clinical situations.

questions.text: Rinku devi, a 26 years old female, labourer by occupation presented to you with complains of pain abdomen, nausea and restlessness since 4 hours. She gives h/o 2 episodes of hematuria. USG showed a 3×3 cm stone in Right renal pelvis. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis. Which of following is the best procedure for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PCNL:

  • PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy) is the best procedure for the management of kidney stones > 2 cm in size. 
  • Management of Kidney stones
    • Ketrolac/Tramadol
    • Euvolemia is achieved via IVF (prevents dehydration)
    • Alpha-1 blocker (Tamsulosin) can be given to relax ureter and expels the stone.
    • <2 cm kidney stone- Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (contraindicated in pregnancy bleeding diathesis)
    • > 2 cm kidney stone- PCNL (Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy)
    • Ureteric stone (lower 1/3rd): Endourological appraoch- Dormian basket.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ESWL: ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy) is a non-invasive procedure done for kidney stones <2 cm. 

Option C - Antegrade Pyeloplasty: Antegrade Pyeloplasty is a surgical procedure used to treat ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction.

Option D - Retrograde pyeloplasty: Retrograde Pyeloplasty is also a surgical procedure used for the treatment of UPJ obstruction.

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap from the following values:

Na+ = 137 mmol/L

K+ = 4 mmol/L

CI- = 100 mmol/L

HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
Correct Option:  A) 22 mmol/L

 

The anion gap is a calculated value used to evaluate the cause of a metabolic acidosis. It represents the difference between the measured cations and measured anions in the blood.

The standard formula for calculating the anion gap is:

Anion Gap = [Na⁺] - ([Cl⁻] + [HCO₃⁻])

Given the values: [Na+] = 137 mmol/L

[Cl-] = 100 mmol/L

[HCO3-] = 15 mmol/L

Anion Gap = 137 - (100 + 15) = 137 - 115 = 22 mmol/L

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents to the OPD with pedal edema and facial puffiness for the past 5 days. BP was 126/80 mm Hg, proteinuria 3+. Urine examination shows 100 RBCs/hpf. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is type 3 hypersensitivity reaction followed by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci.
  • It commonly affects children and presents with symptoms such as pedal edema (swelling of the feet), facial puffiness, hypertension (elevated blood pressure), and proteinuria (presence of excess protein in the urine).
  • In PSGN, the immune response triggered by the streptococcal infection causes formation of immune complexes by an antigen called Streptococcal pyrogenic
    exotoxin B (SPEP).
  • This is distributed in the renal parenchyma damagin the blood vessels contributing to liguria, increaased renin (HTN)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Minimal change disease:

  • Hematuria (presence of RBCs in urine) is less common in minimal change disease, and when present, it's usually microscopic rather than gross.
  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome characterized by proteinuria (typically massive), hypoalbuminemia, and edema.

 

Option C - Membranous glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome but is more common in adults.
  • Proteinuria is usually moderate to severe and may not be accompanied by gross hematuria.
  • Edema and hypertension can be present but are less common in children.

Option D - Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis:

  • Presents with nephrotic syndrome but is also more common in adults.
  • Proteinuria can be massive but is typically accompanied by microscopic hematuria rather than gross hematuria.
  • Edema and hypertension may be present but are less common in children.

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute kidney injury:

  • AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and diagnose acute kidney injury (AKI). These criteria provide a standardized approach for assessing the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine levels, urine output, and the duration of kidney dysfunction.

Criteria

AKIN

RIFLE

Definition

Based on changes in serum creatinine and urine output.

Based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and GFR.

Serum Creatinine

Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours or ≥1.5 times baseline within 7 days.

R (Risk): Increase in serum creatinine ≥1.5 times baseline or GFR decrease >25%.

I (Injury): Increase in serum creatinine ≥2 times baseline or GFR decrease >50%.

F (Failure): Increase in serum creatinine ≥3 times baseline or GFR decrease >75%.

Urine Output

Decreased urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/hour for >6 hours).

O (Loss): Persistent acute kidney injury with complete loss of kidney function for >4 weeks.

E (End-stage kidney disease): Persistent acute kidney injury with complete loss of kidney function for >3 months.

Staging

AKIN stage 1: Increase in serum creatinine ≥0.3 mg/dL or ≥1.5 times baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6-12 hours.

AKIN stage 2: Increase in serum creatinine ≥2 times baseline or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/hour for ≥12 hours.

AKIN stage 3: Increase in serum creatinine ≥3 times baseline or serum creatinine ≥4.0 mg/dL or initiation of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or urine output <0.3 mL/kg/hour for ≥24 hours or anuria for ≥12 hours.

RIFLE classifies severity based on the R, I, F, O, and E criteria.

Clinical Application

Used in research, clinical trials, and clinical practice for AKI diagnosis and staging.

Widely used in research, clinical trials, and clinical practice for AKI diagnosis, classification, and outcome assessment.

Limitations

Relies on serum creatinine and urine output, which can be influenced by factors such as age, muscle mass, fluid status, and medications.

Similar limitations as AKIN criteria.

More recent studies suggest that RIFLE may be more predictive of mortality and need for RRT.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chronic renal failure: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are specifically designed to classify acute kidney injury and are not applicable to chronic renal failure. 

Option C - Acute glomerulonephritis: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify acute glomerulonephritis. 

Option D - Nephrotic syndrome: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease came with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. His blood gas reports show pH = 7.40, HC03- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, anion gap= 100 mEq/L. What is your probable diagnosis?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis:

  • Normal pH of 7.40- Indicates no primary acid-base abnormality. However, the
  • Bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 23 mEq/L falls within the normal range- Suggests that there is a compensatory mechanism in place. 
  • Sodium (Na+) level of 145 mEq/L is also within the normal range.
  • Elevated anion gap of 100 mEq/L, which indicates the presence of an underlying metabolic acidosis.
  • High anion gap metabolic acidosis is commonly seen in conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and renal failure. In this case, the patient's chronic kidney disease is likely contributing to the development of high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • Increased anion gap but HCO3 is not reciprocally reduced indicating presence of metabolic alkalosis component. 
  • The above findings suggests a diagnosis of High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No acid-base abnormality: This choice is incorrect because the blood gas reports indicate the presence of an abnormality, specifically a high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

Option B - Respiratory acidosis: The blood gas reports do not show any abnormalities in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2), which is a key indicator of respiratory acidosis. 

Option C - Metabolic alkalosis: This choice is incorrect because it only accounts for the metabolic alkalosis component of the patient's acid-base disturbance.

questions.text: A 10 year old male child was brought with complains of headache, cola colored urine. His parents give history of throat pain 2 weeks ago. On examination, red blood cells casts are present in urine and his KFT is increased two fold. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Post infectious Glomerulonephritis:

  • The likely diagnosis of the above patient is Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis.
  • Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis: This is a type of nephritic syndrome that occurs after an infection, most commonly caused by group A beta hemolytic streptococcus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Minimal change disease: Minimal change disease is characterized by minimal changes in the glomeruli on microscopic examination and is commonly seen in children. It typically presents with proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia.

Option B - Membranous Glomerulopathy: Membranous glomerulopathy characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane due to immune complex deposits. It typically presents with proteinuria, edema, and hypoalbuminemia.

Option D - IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy is the most common glomerulonephritis that develops in a patient with URTI within 48 hours.
